title: America bans Vegemite

title: Re: America bans Vegemite
content:
[url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Folic_acid]en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Folic_acid[/url]

So it seems that in order to counter birth defects, they made a law stating that folate had to be added to some food, and consequently, this meant that ONLY that food was allowed additional folate. Vegemite contains added folic acid and is thus against the law.
Crazy American laws! [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-rolleyes.gif[/img] ----------

title: Re: America bans Vegemite
content:
Vegemite is a yeast extract; basically you take the gunk left over after brewing beer [thus australia has a lot of ot] booil it down to a black paste and put it into tiny little jars.

It tastes like a blocked lavatory, and thus like most australian food, hence its wide aceptance there.

title: re:
content:
[img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-lol.gif[/img]

You people are obviously putting far too much on. You want to cook some toast, smother it with butter, and then spread the tiniest, thinnest layer of Vegemite possible over it. Tastes beautiful.

The good thing about it being so strong is that you don't use much at a time... the stuff lasts for ages!

title: Re: re:
content: Ugh... butter... [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-sick.gif[/img]

title: Re: re:
content:
Well, like most "native" foods it's probably an acquired taste. If you didn't grow up with it (and for a small number of people even if you did), you won't like it. I quite like the taste, to me it's just a tangy salty spread, and I don't mind putting a thick layer on toast. Yum [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

If you don't like it that's fine, don't buy it, but don't force your dislike on others by trying to get it banned [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-cheeky.gif[/img]

title: heheh
content:
I travelled to Australia on a trip with my school band during the summer of 1997... I was 14 at the time. I tried some Vegemite on toast one morning--the host family I was staying with laughed when I said I wasn't thrilled with the flavor, and they gave me a little jar of it to take home with me. All I can remember of it is a very salty taste and a vague vegetable color.

Oddly enough, my girlfriend's father (and one of her brothers) loves the stuff and eats it on toast all the time.

title: Re: heheh
content:
Aye, owned by the company formally known as Philip Morris - I'm sure you've heard of Marlborough cigarettes? Same owners.

Also, snopes.com says:
[quote]Quote:[hr]The US government has dismissed media reports it had banned Vegemite.

"There is no ban on Vegemite," US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) spokesman Mike Herndon said.

Media reports claimed American border officials were confiscating Vegemite from Australians as they entered the US.

The FDA, charged with policing America's food supply, has not issued an "import alert" to border officials to halt the import of Vegemite.

Mr Herndon said the FDA was surprised by the media reports.

The controversy centres on folate, an ingredient in Vegemite.

Under US regulations, folate can be added only to breads and cereals.

"One of the Vitamin B components (in Vegemite) is folate," Mr. Herndon said.

"In and of itself, it's not a violation. If they're adding folate to it, boosting it up, technically it would be a violation.

"But the FDA has not targeted it and I don't think we intend to target Vegemite simply because of that."

Joanna Scott, spokesperson for Vegemite's maker, Kraft, reportedly has said, "The Food and Drug Administration doesn't allow the import of Vegemite simply because the recipe does have the addition of folic acid".

But Mr. Herndon said, "Nobody at the FDA has told them (Kraft) there is a ban".[hr][/quote]------------------
